paragraph.content: a class of matching procedures;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (3), the conditions, if any, subject to which a matching procedure belonging to that class shall be carried out.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner shall, before specifying any conditions in a notice under subsection (2), consult with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such bodies representative of data users to which the conditions will apply (whether in whole or in part); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other interested persons,

subsection.continued: as he thinks fit.

subsection.content: It is hereby declared that a notice under subsection (2) is subsidiary legislation.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), a data user shall not take adverse action against an individual in consequence (whether in whole or in part) of the carrying out of a matching procedure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: unless the data user has served a notice in writing on the individual—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: specifying the adverse action it proposes to take and the reasons therefor; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: stating that the individual has 7 days after the receipt of the notice within which to show cause why that action should not be taken; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: until the expiration of those 7 days.

subsection.content: Subsection (5) shall not operate to prevent a data user from taking adverse action against an individual if compliance with the requirements of that subsection would prejudice any investigation into the commission of an offence or the possible commission of an offence.

subsection.leadIn: A data user proposing to carry out, whether in whole or in part, a matching procedure may make a request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the specified form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to the Commissioner; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: seeking the Commissioner’s consent under section 32 to the carrying out of that procedure.

subsection.content: Where 2 or more data users may each make a matching procedure request in respect of the same matching procedure, then any of those data users may make such a request on behalf of all those data users, and the provisions of this Ordinance (including subsection (1)) shall be construed accordingly.

Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (2), it is hereby declared that a matching procedure request may be made in relation to 2 or more matching procedures, or a series of matching procedures, and the other provisions of this Ordinance (including section 32) shall be construed accordingly.

A data user who, in a matching procedure request made under subsection (1), supplies any information which is false or misleading in a material particular for the purpose of obtaining the Commissioner’s consent to the carrying out of the matching procedure to which the request relates, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 18)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner shall determine a matching procedure request—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: not later than 45 days after receiving the request; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: by taking into account the prescribed matters applicable to the request and—

subparagraph.content: where he is satisfied as to those matters, serving a notice in writing on the requestor stating that he consents to the carrying out of the matching procedure to which the request relates subject to the conditions, if any, specified in the notice;

subparagraph.leadIn: where he is not so satisfied, serving a notice in writing on the requestor stating—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: that he refuses to consent to the carrying out of the matching procedure to which the request relates; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: such of those matters in respect of which he is not so satisfied and the reasons why he is not so satisfied.

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that a consent in a notice under subsection (1)(b)(i) to the carrying out of a matching procedure to which a matching procedure request relates shall not operate to prevent a data user who is neither the requestor nor, where section 31(2) applies to the request, any data user on whose behalf such request was made, from carrying out, whether in whole or in part, the procedure.

subsection.leadIn: An appeal may be made to the Administrative Appeals Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: against—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the requestor on whom the notice was served or any data user on whose behalf the matching procedure request concerned was made.

subsection.def: In this section, prescribed matter (訂明事宜) means a matter specified in Schedule 5.

subsection.content: A requestor who contravenes any conditions specified in a notice under subsection (1)(b)(i) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 19)

section.name: s33
section.heading: Prohibition against transfer of personal data to place outside Hong Kong except in specified circumstances

subsection.leadIn: This section shall not apply to personal data other than personal data the collection, holding, processing or use of which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: takes place in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is controlled by a data user whose principal place of business is in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: A data user shall not transfer personal data to a place outside Hong Kong unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the place is specified for the purposes of this section in a notice under subsection (3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the user has reasonable grounds for believing that there is in force in that place any law which is substantially similar to, or serves the same purposes as, this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the data subject has consented in writing to the transfer;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the user has reasonable grounds for believing that, in all the circumstances of the case—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the transfer is for the avoidance or mitigation of adverse action against the data subject;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to obtain the consent in writing of the data subject to that transfer; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if it was practicable to obtain such consent, the data subject would give it;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the data is exempt from data protection principle 3 by virtue of an exemption under Part 8; or (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the user has taken all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to ensure that the data will not, in that place, be collected, held, processed or used in any manner which, if that place were Hong Kong, would be a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Where the Commissioner has reasonable grounds for believing that there is in force in a place outside Hong Kong any law which is substantially similar to, or serves the same purposes as, this Ordinance, he may, by notice in the Gazette, specify that place for the purposes of this section.

Where the Commissioner has reasonable grounds for believing that in a place specified in a notice under subsection (3) there is no longer in force any law which is substantially similar to, or serves the same purposes as, this Ordinance, he shall, either by repealing or amending that notice, cause that place to cease to be specified for the purposes of this section.

subsection.leadIn: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes of subsection (1)(b), a data user which is a company incorporated in Hong Kong is a data user whose principal place of business is in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notice under subsection (3) is subsidiary legislation; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: this section shall not operate to prejudice the generality of section 50.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Repeated collections of personal data in same circumstances

subsection.leadIn: A data user who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has complied with the provisions of data protection principle 1(3) in respect of the collection of any personal data from the data subject (first collection); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on any subsequent occasion again collects personal data from the data subject (subsequent collection),

subsection.continued: is not required to comply with those provisions in respect of the subsequent collection if, but only if—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: to comply with those provisions in respect of that subsequent collection would be to repeat, without any material difference, what was done to comply with that principle in respect of the first collection; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: not more than 12 months have elapsed between the first collection and the subsequent collection.

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that subsection (1) shall not operate to prevent a subsequent collection from becoming a first collection if, but only if, the data user concerned has complied with the provisions of data protection principle 1(3) in respect of the subsequent collection.

part.name: P6A
part.heading: Use of Personal Data in Direct Marketing and Provision of Personal Data for Use in Direct Marketing

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: consent (同意), in relation to a use of personal data in direct marketing or a provision of personal data for use in direct marketing, includes an indication of no objection to the use or provision;

def.name: DirectMarketing
def.leadIn: direct marketing (直接促銷) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the offering, or advertising of the availability, of goods, facilities or services; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the solicitation of donations or contributions for charitable, cultural, philanthropic, recreational, political or other purposes,

def.name: DirectMarketingMeans
def.leadIn: direct marketing means (直接促銷方法) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sending information or goods, addressed to specific persons by name, by mail, fax, electronic mail or other means of communication; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making telephone calls to specific persons;

def.name: MarketingSubject
def.leadIn: marketing subject (促銷標的), in relation to direct marketing, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any goods, facility or service offered, or the availability of which is advertised; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any purpose for which donations or contributions are solicited;

def.name: PermittedClassOfMarketingSubjects
def.leadIn: permitted class of marketing subjects (許可類別促銷標的), in relation to a consent by a data subject to an intended use or provision of personal data, means a class of marketing subjects—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in relation to which the consent is given;

def.name: PermittedClassOfPersons
def.leadIn: permitted class of persons (許可類別人士), in relation to a consent by a data subject to an intended provision of personal data, means a class of persons—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is specified in the information provided to the data subject under section 35J(2)(b)(iii); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to which the consent is given;

def.name: PermittedKindOfPersonalData
def.leadIn: permitted kind of personal data (許可種類個人資料), in relation to a consent by a data subject to an intended use or provision of personal data, means a kind of personal data—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in relation to which the consent is given;

subsection.def: response channel (回應途徑) means a channel provided by a data user to a data subject under section 35C(2)(c) or 35J(2)(c).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part, a person provides personal data for gain if the person provides personal data in return for money or other property, irrespective of whether—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the return is contingent on any condition; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person retains any control over the use of the data.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Use of Personal Data in Direct Marketing

section.name: s35B
section.heading: Application
section.leadIn: This Division does not apply in relation to the offering, or advertising of the availability, of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: social services run, subvented or subsidized by the Social Welfare Department;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: health care services provided by the Hospital Authority or Department of Health; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: any other social or health care services which, if not provided, would be likely to cause serious harm to the physical or mental health of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the individual to whom the services are intended to be provided; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any other individual.

section.name: s35C
section.heading: Data user to take specified action before using personal data in direct marketing

subsection.content: Subject to section 35D, a data user who intends to use a data subject’s personal data in direct marketing must take each of the actions specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The data user must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: inform the data subject—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the data user intends to so use the personal data; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that the data user may not so use the data unless the data user has received the data subject’s consent to the intended use;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: provide the data subject with the following information in relation to the intended use—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the kinds of personal data to be used; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the classes of marketing subjects in relation to which the data is to be used; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide the data subject with a channel through which the data subject may, without charge by the data user, communicate the data subject’s consent to the intended use.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) applies irrespective of whether the personal data is collected from the data subject by the data user.
The information provided under subsection (2)(a) and (b) must be presented in a manner that is easily understandable and, if in written form, easily readable.

Subject to section 35D, a data user who uses a data subject’s personal data in direct marketing without taking each of the actions specified in subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (5), it is a defence for the data user charged to prove that the data user took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.
In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (5), the burden of proving that this section does not apply because of section 35D lies on the data user.

section.name: s35D
section.heading: Circumstances under which section 35C does not apply

subsection.leadIn: If, before the commencement date—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a data subject had been explicitly informed by a data user in an easily understandable and, if informed in writing, easily readable manner of the intended use or use of the data subject’s personal data in direct marketing in relation to a class of marketing subjects;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the data user had so used any of the data;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the data subject had not required the data user to cease to so use any of the data; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the data user had not, in relation to the use, contravened any provision of this Ordinance as in force as at the time of the use,

subsection.continued: then section 35C does not apply in relation to the intended use or use, on or after the commencement date*, of the data subject’s relevant personal data, as updated from time to time, in direct marketing in relation to the class of marketing subjects.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a data subject’s personal data is provided to a data user by a person other than the data subject (third person); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the third person has by notice in writing to the data user—

subparagraph.content: stated that sections 35J and 35K have been complied with in relation to the provision of data; and
specified the class of marketing subjects in relation to which the data may be used in direct marketing by the data user, as consented to by the data subject,

subsection.continued: then section 35C does not apply in relation to the intended use or use by the data user of the data in direct marketing in relation to that class of marketing subjects.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: *commencement date (本部生效日期) means the date on which this Part comes into operation;
relevant personal data (有關個人資料), in relation to a data subject, means any personal data of the data subject over the use of which a data user had control immediately before the commencement date.

section.name: s35E
section.heading: Data user must not use personal data in direct marketing without data subject’s consent

subsection.leadIn: A data user who has complied with section 35C must not use the data subject’s personal data in direct marketing unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the data user has received the data subject’s consent to the intended use of personal data, as described in the information provided by the data user under section 35C(2)(b), either generally or selectively;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the consent is given orally, the data user has, within 14 days from receiving the consent, sent a written confirmation to the data subject, confirming—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the date of receipt of the consent;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the permitted kind of personal data; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the permitted class of marketing subjects; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the use is consistent with the data subject’s consent.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(c), the use of personal data is consistent with the data subject’s consent if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the personal data falls within a permitted kind of personal data; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the marketing subject in relation to which the data is used falls within a permitted class of marketing subjects.

subsection.content: A data subject may communicate to a data user the consent to a use of personal data either through a response channel or other means.
A data user who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (4), it is a defence for the data user charged to prove that the data user took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.

section.name: s35F
section.heading: Data user must notify data subject when using personal data in direct marketing for first time

subsection.content: A data user must, when using a data subject’s personal data in direct marketing for the first time, inform the data subject that the data user must, without charge to the data subject, cease to use the data in direct marketing if the data subject so requires.
Subsection (1) applies irrespective of whether the personal data is collected from the data subject by the data user.
A data user who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (3), it is a defence for the data user charged to prove that the data user took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.

section.name: s35G
section.heading: Data subject may require data user to cease to use personal data in direct marketing

subsection.content: A data subject may, at any time, require a data user to cease to use the data subject’s personal data in direct marketing.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) applies irrespective of whether the data subject—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has received from the data user the information required to be provided in relation to the use of personal data under section 35C(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has earlier given consent to the data user or a third person to the use.

subsection.content: A data user who receives a requirement from a data subject under subsection (1) must, without charge to the data subject, comply with the requirement.
A data user who contravenes subsection (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (4), it is a defence for the data user charged to prove that the data user took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.
This section does not affect the operation of section 26.

section.name: s35H
section.heading: Prescribed consent for using personal data in direct marketing under data protection principle 3
section.content: Despite section 2(3), where a data user requires, under data protection principle 3, the prescribed consent of a data subject for using any personal data of the data subject in direct marketing, the data user is to be taken to have obtained the consent if the data user has not contravened section 35C, 35E or 35G.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Provision of Personal Data for Use in Direct Marketing

subsection.leadIn: This Division does not apply if a data user provides, otherwise than for gain, personal data of a data subject to another person for use by that other person in offering, or advertising the availability, of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: social services run, subvented or subsidized by the Social Welfare Department;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: health care services provided by the Hospital Authority or Department of Health; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: any other social or health care services which, if not provided, would be likely to cause serious harm to the physical or mental health of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the individual to whom the services are intended to be provided; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any other individual.

subsection.content: This Division does not apply if a data user provides personal data of a data subject to an agent of the data user for use by the agent in carrying out direct marketing on the data user’s behalf.

section.name: s35J
section.heading: Data user to take specified action before providing personal data

subsection.content: A data user who intends to provide a data subject’s personal data to another person for use by that other person in direct marketing must take each of the actions specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The data user must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: inform the data subject in writing—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the data user intends to so provide the personal data; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that the data user may not so provide the data unless the data user has received the data subject’s written consent to the intended provision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: provide the data subject with the following written information in relation to the intended provision—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the data is to be provided for gain, that the data is to be so provided;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the kinds of personal data to be provided;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the classes of persons to which the data is to be provided; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the classes of marketing subjects in relation to which the data is to be used; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide the data subject with a channel through which the data subject may, without charge by the data user, communicate the data subject’s consent to the intended provision in writing.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) applies irrespective of whether the personal data is collected from the data subject by the data user.
The information provided under subsection (2)(a) and (b) must be presented in a manner that is easily understandable and easily readable.

subsection.leadIn: A data user who provides personal data of a data subject to another person for use by that other person in direct marketing without taking each of the actions specified in subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the data is provided for gain, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the data is provided otherwise than for gain, to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.content: In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (5), it is a defence for the data user charged to prove that the data user took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.

section.name: s35K
section.heading: Data user must not provide personal data for use in direct marketing without data subject’s consent

subsection.leadIn: A data user who has complied with section 35J must not provide the data subject’s personal data to another person for use by that other person in direct marketing unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the data user has received the data subject’s written consent to the intended provision of personal data, as described in the information provided by the data user under section 35J(2)(b), either generally or selectively;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the data is provided for gain, the intention to so provide was specified in the information under section 35J(2)(b)(i); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the provision is consistent with the data subject’s consent.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(c), the provision of personal data is consistent with the data subject’s consent if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the personal data falls within a permitted kind of personal data;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person to whom the data is provided falls within a permitted class of persons; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the marketing subject in relation to which the data is to be used falls within a permitted class of marketing subjects.

subsection.content: A data subject may communicate to a data user the consent to a provision of personal data either through a response channel or other written means.

subsection.leadIn: A data user who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the data user provides the personal data for gain, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the data user provides the personal data otherwise than for gain, to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.content: In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (4), it is a defence for the data user charged to prove that the data user took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.

section.name: s35L
section.heading: Data subject may require data user to cease to provide personal data for use in direct marketing

subsection.leadIn: A data subject who has been provided with information by a data user under section 35J(2)(b) may, at any time, require the data user—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to cease to provide the data subject’s personal data to any other person for use by that other person in direct marketing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to notify any person to whom the data has been so provided to cease to use the data in direct marketing.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) applies irrespective of whether the data subject has earlier given consent to the provision of the personal data.
A data user who receives a requirement from a data subject under subsection (1) must, without charge to the data subject, comply with the requirement.

If a data user is required to notify a person to cease to use a data subject’s personal data in direct marketing under a requirement referred to in subsection (1)(b), the data user must so notify the person in writing.
A person who receives a written notification from a data user under subsection (4) must cease to use the personal data in direct marketing in accordance with the notification.

subsection.leadIn: A data user who contravenes subsection (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the contravention involves a provision of personal data of a data subject for gain, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (5) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (6) or (7), it is a defence for the data user or person charged to prove that the data user or person took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.
This section does not affect the operation of section 26.

section.name: s35M
section.heading: Prescribed consent for providing personal data for use in direct marketing under data protection principle 3
section.content: Despite section 2(3), where a data user requires, under data protection principle 3, the prescribed consent of a data subject for providing any personal data of the data subject to another person for use in direct marketing, the data user is to be taken to have obtained the consent if the data user has not contravened section 35J, 35K or 35L.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Inspections of personal data systems
section.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of section 38, the Commissioner may carry out an inspection of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any personal data system used by a data user; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any personal data system used by a data user belonging to a class of data users,

section.continued: for the purposes of ascertaining information to assist the Commissioner in making recommendations—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.leadIn: to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: where paragraph (a) is applicable, the relevant data user;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: where paragraph (b) is applicable, the class of data users to which the relevant data user belongs; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: relating to the promotion of compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance, in particular the data protection principles, by the relevant data user, or the class of data users to which the relevant data user belongs, as the case may be.

subsection.leadIn: An individual, or a relevant person on behalf of an individual, may make a complaint to the Commissioner about an act or practice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specified in the complaint; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has been done or engaged in, or is being done or engaged in, as the case may be, by a data user specified in the complaint;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: relates to personal data of which the individual is or, in any case in which the data user is relying upon an exemption under Part 8, may be, the data subject; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: may be a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance (including section 28(4)).

subsection.content: Where 2 or more individuals may each make a complaint about the same act or practice, then any of those individuals, or any relevant person on behalf of any of those individuals, may make such a complaint on behalf of all those individuals, and the provisions of this Ordinance (including subsection (1)) shall be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: A complaint shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in writing in the Chinese or English language; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in such other form as the Commissioner may accept.

subsection.content: It shall be the duty of the Commissioner and each prescribed officer who has been employed under section 9(1)(a) to provide appropriate assistance to an individual, or a relevant person on behalf of an individual, who wishes to make a complaint and requires assistance to formulate the complaint.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Investigations by Commissioner
section.leadIn: Where the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: receives a complaint; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: has reasonable grounds to believe that an act or practice—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has been done or engaged in, or is being done or engaged in, as the case may be, by a data user;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: relates to personal data; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: may be a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance,

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: where paragraph (a) is applicable, the Commissioner shall, subject to section 39, carry out an investigation in relation to the relevant data user to ascertain whether the act or practice specified in the complaint is a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: where paragraph (b) is applicable, the Commissioner may carry out an investigation in relation to the relevant data user to ascertain whether the act or practice referred to in that paragraph is a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Restrictions on investigations initiated by complaints

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding the generality of the powers conferred on the Commissioner by this Ordinance, the Commissioner may refuse to carry out or decide to terminate an investigation initiated by a complaint if— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 22)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the complainant (or, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person) has had actual knowledge of the act or practice specified in the complaint for more than 2 years immediately preceding the date on which the Commissioner received the complaint, unless the Commissioner is satisfied that in all the circumstances of the case it is proper to carry out or not to terminate, as the case may be, the investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the complaint is made anonymously;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the complainant cannot be identified or traced;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: none of the following conditions is fulfilled in respect of the act or practice specified in the complaint—

subparagraph.name: i
A
subparagraph.content: the complainant (or, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person) was resident in Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the relevant data user was able to control, in or from Hong Kong, the collection, holding, processing or use of the personal data concerned,

subparagraph.continued: at any time the act or practice was done or engaged in, as the case may be;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the complainant (or, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person) was in Hong Kong at any time the act or practice was done or engaged in, as the case may be;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the opinion of the Commissioner, the act or practice done or engaged in, as the case may be, may prejudice the enforcement of any right, or the exercise of any privilege, acquired or accrued in Hong Kong by the complainant (or, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person); (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 4)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Commissioner is satisfied that the relevant data user has not been a data user for a period of not less than 2 years immediately preceding the date on which the Commissioner received the complaint; or (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 4)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Commissioner is of the opinion that the complaint relates to an offence under section 64(1), (3A) or (3C) and decides to carry out a specified investigation (as defined by section 66C). (Added 32 of 2021 s. 4)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may refuse to carry out or decide to terminate an investigation initiated by a complaint if he is of the opinion that, having regard to all the circumstances of the case— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 22)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the complaint, or a complaint of a substantially similar nature, has previously initiated an investigation as a result of which the Commissioner was of the opinion that there had been no contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the act or practice specified in the complaint is trivial;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the complaint is frivolous or vexatious or is not made in good faith;

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: the primary subject matter of the complaint, as shown by the act or practice specified in it, is not related to privacy of individuals in relation to personal data; or (Added 18 of 2012 s. 22)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any investigation or further investigation is for any other reason unnecessary.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commissioner refuses under this section to carry out an investigation initiated by a complaint, he shall, as soon as practicable but, in any case, not later than 45 days after receiving the complaint, by notice in writing served on the complainant accompanied by a copy of subsection (4), inform the complainant— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 22)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of the refusal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of the reasons for the refusal.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner decides to terminate an investigation initiated by a complaint before its completion, the Commissioner must, as soon as practicable by notice in writing served on the complainant accompanied by a copy of subsection (4), inform the complainant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of the reasons for the decision. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 22)

subsection.leadIn: An appeal may be made to the Administrative Appeals Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: against any refusal or termination specified in a notice under subsection (3) or (3A); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the complainant on whom the notice was served (or, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person, or either).

section.name: s40
section.heading: Commissioner may carry out or continue investigation initiated by complaint notwithstanding withdrawal of complaint
section.content: Where the Commissioner is of the opinion that it is in the public interest so to do, he may carry out or continue an investigation initiated by a complaint notwithstanding that the complainant has withdrawn the complaint and, in any such case, the provisions of this Ordinance shall apply to the complaint and the complainant as if the complaint had not been withdrawn.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Commissioner to inform relevant data user of inspection or investigation

subsection.content: The Commissioner shall, before carrying out an inspection or, subject to subsection (2), an investigation, by notice in writing served on the relevant data user, inform the data user of his intention to carry out the inspection or investigation, as the case may be.

The Commissioner is not required to comply with subsection (1) in the case of any investigation in respect of which he has reasonable grounds to believe that to so comply may prejudice the purposes of the investigation.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Power of entry on premises for the purposes of an inspection or investigation

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (3) and (8), the Commissioner may, for the purposes of an inspection—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: where the personal data system, or any part thereof, the subject of the inspection is situated in—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: non-domestic premises, enter the premises at any reasonable time;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: domestic premises, enter the premises with the consent of any person (other than a minor) resident therein;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: carry out in the premises the inspection.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (3) and (8), the Commissioner may, for the purposes of an investigation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: enter any premises—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: occupied by the relevant data user; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in which is situated the personal data system, or any part thereof, used by the relevant data user;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: carry out in the premises the investigation.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (4) and (5), the Commissioner shall, not less than 14 days before exercising his power under subsection (1) or (2) in respect of any premises, by notice in writing served on the relevant data user, inform the data user—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of the premises in respect of which he proposes to exercise that power; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the power will not be so exercised before the expiration of 14 days after service of the notice.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the generality of subsection (5), where any domestic premises are specified in a notice under subsection (3) in respect of which the Commissioner proposes to exercise his power under subsection (2), then the Commissioner shall not exercise that power in respect of those premises unless and until a person (other than a minor) resident therein consents thereto before the expiration of 14 days after service of the notice.

The Commissioner may, pursuant to a warrant issued under subsection (6), exercise his power under subsection (2) in respect of the premises specified in the warrant without complying with subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may, if satisfied by information upon oath by the Commissioner or any prescribed officer that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the purposes of any investigation may be substantially prejudiced if the Commissioner were required to comply with subsection (3) before exercising his power under subsection (2) in respect of any premises, issue a warrant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the form specified in Part 1 of Schedule 6; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in respect of those premises.

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may, if satisfied by information upon oath by the Commissioner or any prescribed officer that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the purposes of an investigation may be substantially prejudiced if the Commissioner is prevented by the operation of subsection (4) from exercising his power under subsection (2) in respect of any domestic premises, issue a warrant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the form specified in Part 2 of Schedule 6; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: authorizing the Commissioner to exercise that power in respect of those premises.

subsection.content: The Commissioner shall not exercise his power under subsection (1) or (2) in respect of any premises in such a way as to unduly disrupt any operations being carried out in the premises, whether by the relevant data user or any other person.

Where the Commissioner exercises his power under subsection (1) or (2), the relevant data user shall, without charge, afford the Commissioner such facilities and assistance as the Commissioner may reasonably require for the purposes of the inspection or investigation concerned.

Where the Commissioner, pursuant to a warrant issued under subsection (6), exercises his power under subsection (2) in respect of the premises specified in the warrant, he shall produce the warrant for inspection by any person found in those premises who questions his authority to exercise that power in respect of those premises.

subsection.leadIn: In this section and Schedule 6—
subsection.def: domestic premises (住宅處所) means any premises which are constructed or intended to be used for habitation;
non-domestic premises (非住宅處所) means any premises other than domestic premises;

def.name: Premises
def.leadIn: premises (處所) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any building where no part of the building is separately occupied, and includes any land appertaining to the building;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, any part of a building which is separately occupied, and includes any land appertaining to such part.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, the Commissioner may, for the purposes of any investigation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be furnished with any information, document or thing, from such persons, and make such inquiries, as he thinks fit; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: regulate his procedure in such manner as he thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: Any hearing for the purposes of an investigation shall be carried out in public unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner is of the opinion that, in all the circumstances of the case, the investigation should be carried out in private; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the investigation was initiated by a complaint, the complainant requests in writing that the investigation be carried out in private.

subsection.content: Counsel and solicitors shall not have any right of audience before the Commissioner at any hearing for the purposes of an investigation, but may appear before him if he thinks fit.
It shall not be necessary for the Commissioner to hold any hearing for the purposes of an investigation and no person shall be entitled to be heard by the Commissioner.

If at any time during the course of an investigation it appears to the Commissioner that there may be sufficient grounds for him to make any report or recommendation that may criticize or adversely affect any person he shall give to the person an opportunity to be heard.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2) and section 45, the Commissioner may, for the purposes of any investigation, summon before him any person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the opinion of the Commissioner, is able to give any information relevant to those purposes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the investigation was initiated by a complaint, is the complainant (or, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person, or both),

subsection.continued: and may examine any such person and require him to furnish to the Commissioner any information and to produce any document or thing which, in the opinion of the Commissioner, is relevant to those purposes and which may be in the possession or under the control of any such person.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an investigation has been initiated by a complaint;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the complaint relates, whether in whole or in part, to personal data referred to in section 61(1);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Commissioner has, for the purposes of that investigation, under subsection (1)(a) summoned before him a person; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: that person asserts, in response to any requirement under subsection (1) by the Commissioner to furnish him with information or to produce a document or thing, that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to comply with that requirement would directly or indirectly disclose the identity of the individual from whom that data was collected (whether in whole or in part); or (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 23)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: he is not required to comply with that requirement by virtue of any common law privilege,

subsection.continued: then—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: notwithstanding any other provision of this Ordinance, the Commissioner shall not serve an enforcement notice on that person in relation to that requirement;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the Commissioner may, not later than 28 days after that assertion is made known to him, make an application to the Court of First Instance for an order directing that person to comply with that requirement; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.leadIn: the Court of First Instance may make the order if, but only if, it is satisfied, having regard to all the circumstances (including the circumstances of the complainant), that— (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: if the act or practice specified in the complaint were proven to be a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance, the contravention would be of sufficient gravity to warrant that person complying with the requirement referred to in paragraph (d);

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: that investigation would be substantially prejudiced if the requirement referred to in paragraph (d) were not compiled with;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: it is in the public interest, having regard to the benefit likely to accrue to that investigation, that the requirement referred to in paragraph (d) be complied with; and

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: in any case to which paragraph (d)(ii) is applicable, the common law privilege asserted does not apply; and

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: on the hearing of the application, the Commissioner, that person and the complainant shall each be entitled to be heard on the application and to call, examine and cross-examine any witness.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person has complied with a requirement referred to in subsection (2)(d) the subject of an assertion referred to in that subsection; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the result (whether in whole or in part) of the investigation to which that requirement relates is that the Commissioner is of the opinion that the individual concerned referred to in subsection (2)(d)(i) has not contravened a requirement under this Ordinance in relation to the matter the subject of the complaint which initiated the investigation,

subsection.continued: then, notwithstanding any other provision of this Ordinance, neither the Commissioner nor any prescribed officer shall disclose the identity of that individual to the complainant.

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may, of its own volition or on an application made to it for the purpose, by order reverse, vary or discharge an order made under subsection (2)(iii) or suspend the operation of such an order. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Provision may be made by rules of court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with respect to applications to the Court of First Instance under subsection (2)(iii) or (4);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: generally with respect to procedure before the Court of First Instance in relation to any such application. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.content: Subsection (5) is without prejudice to the generality of any existing power to make rules.
The Commissioner may administer an oath for the purposes of an examination under subsection (1) if he thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: It is hereby declared that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no obligation to maintain secrecy or other restriction, imposed by law, upon the disclosure of any information, document or other thing, that is or has been in the possession or under the control of any person referred to in subsection (1), shall apply to its disclosure for the purposes of an investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any requirement by the Commissioner that any such information, document or thing as is referred to in paragraph (a) be disclosed or produced for the purposes of an investigation shall be sufficient authority for its disclosure or production to the Commissioner.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may pay the reasonable expenses of complainants (including, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person) and witnesses incurred during the course of an investigation.
A person who contravenes subsection (3) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 23)

Every person shall have the same privileges in relation to the giving of information, the answering of questions, and the production of documents and things, for the purposes of an investigation, as witnesses have in civil proceedings in the High Court but any enactment or rule of law which authorizes or requires the withholding of any document or thing, or the refusal to answer any question, on the ground that the disclosure of the document or thing or the answering of the question, as the case may be, would be injurious to the public interest, shall not apply in respect of any investigation. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 18 of 2012 s. 24)

Except on the trial of any person for perjury in respect of his sworn testimony, or for an offence under this Ordinance, no statement made or answer given by that or any other person in the course of any investigation shall be admissible in evidence against any person, before any magistrate or in any court or at any inquiry or in any other proceedings, and no evidence in respect of an investigation shall be given against any person.

Where the giving of any information or the answering of any question or the production of any document or thing would involve the disclosure, without the consent of the Chief Executive, of the deliberations of the Executive Council, the Commissioner shall not require the information or answer to be given or, as the case may be, the document or thing to be produced. (Amended 34 of 1999 s. 3)

Subject to subsections (2), (3), (7) and (8), the Commissioner and every prescribed officer shall maintain secrecy in respect of all matters that come to their actual knowledge in the performance of their functions and the exercise of their powers under this Part. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) shall not operate so as to prevent the Commissioner or any prescribed officer from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (8), disclosing any matter if the disclosure is necessary for the proper performance of the Commissioner’s functions or the proper exercise of the Commissioner’s powers under this Ordinance; (Added 18 of 2012 s. 25)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: disclosing in the course of proceedings—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for an offence under this Ordinance; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: before any court or magistrate,

paragraph.continued: any matter relevant to those proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: reporting evidence of any crime to such authority as he considers appropriate;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: disclosing to a person any matter referred to in subsection (1) which, in the opinion of the Commissioner or prescribed officer, may be ground for a complaint by that person. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), the Commissioner may disclose in any report made by him under this Ordinance any matter that in his opinion ought to be disclosed in order to establish grounds for his findings and recommendations other than a matter the disclosure of which in his opinion would involve the disclosure of personal data that is exempt from data protection principle 6 by virtue of an exemption under Part 8. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: If a report is made by the Commissioner on an inspection or investigation, and the report contains personal data, the Commissioner must not publish the report unless— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 25)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the report in the form in which it is to be published has been supplied to the relevant data user;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that copy is accompanied by a notice in writing inviting the data user to advise the Commissioner, in writing and not later than 28 days after being served with the copy, whether—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the opinion of the data user there is any matter in the copy the disclosure of which would involve the disclosure of personal data that is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 by virtue of an exemption under Part 8; and (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the data user objects to the disclosure of the matter; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the period referred to in paragraph (b) has expired without the Commissioner receiving any such advice; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: such advice is received by the Commissioner and—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the Commissioner deletes from the report the matter the subject of the advice; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.leadIn: the Commissioner decides not to delete that matter from the report and—

subparagraph.name: I
subparagraph.content: the period referred to in subsection (6) expires without the data user making an appeal under that subsection against that decision; or

subparagraph.name: II
subparagraph.content: such an appeal is unsuccessful or withdrawn.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commissioner makes a decision referred to in subsection (4)(c)(ii)(B), he shall serve on the relevant data user who gave the advice concerned a notice in writing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: stating his decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: informing the data user that he may appeal under subsection (6) against that decision; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: accompanied by a copy of this section.

subsection.content: An appeal may be made to the Administrative Appeals Board against a decision of the Commissioner referred to in subsection (4)(c)(ii)(B) by the relevant data user not later than 14 days after the notice under subsection (5) stating that decision has been served on the data user.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, for the purpose of enabling or assisting an authority of a place outside Hong Kong to perform a relevant function of that authority, disclose matters to that authority, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that authority has undertaken to be bound by the secrecy requirements imposed by the Commissioner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the opinion of the Commissioner, there is in force in that place any law which is substantially similar to, or serves the same purposes as, this Ordinance. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, for the proper performance of the Commissioner’s functions or the proper exercise of the Commissioner’s powers under this Ordinance, disclose matters to an authority of a place outside Hong Kong that performs a relevant function, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that authority has undertaken to be bound by the secrecy requirements imposed by the Commissioner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any of the conditions specified in subsection (10) is satisfied. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: In subsections (7) and (8)—
subsection.def: relevant function (有關職能), in relation to an authority of a place outside Hong Kong, means a function relating to investigation into a suspected contravention, and enforcement, of legal or regulatory requirements in that place concerning the protection of privacy of individuals in relation to personal data. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the opinion of the Commissioner, there is in force in that place any law which is substantially similar to, or serves the same purposes as, this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the data subject to whom the matter relates has consented in writing to the disclosure;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the Commissioner has reasonable grounds for believing that, in all the circumstances of the case—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the disclosure is for the avoidance or mitigation of adverse action against the data subject;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: it is not practicable to obtain the consent in writing of the data subject to that disclosure; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if it was practicable to obtain such consent, the data subject would give it;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the personal data to which the matters relate is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 because of an exemption under Part 8; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the Commissioner has taken all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to ensure that the personal data to which the matters relate will not, in that place, be collected, held, processed or used in any manner which, if that place were Hong Kong, would be a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 25)

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 25)

section.name: s47
section.heading: Persons to be informed of result of inspection or investigation

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commissioner has completed an inspection, he shall, in such manner and at such time as he thinks fit, inform the relevant data user of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the result of the inspection;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any recommendations arising from the inspection that the Commissioner thinks fit to make relating to the promotion of compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance, in particular the data protection principles, by the data user;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any report arising from the inspection that he proposes to publish under section 48; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such other comments arising from the inspection as he thinks fit to make.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commissioner has completed an investigation, he shall, in such manner and at such time as he thinks fit, inform the relevant data user of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the result of the investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any recommendations arising from the investigation that the Commissioner thinks fit to make relating to the promotion of compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance, in particular the data protection principles, by the data user;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any report arising from the investigation that he proposes to publish under section 48;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: whether or not he has decided to serve an enforcement notice on the data user in consequence of the investigation; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: such other comments arising from the investigation as he thinks fit to make.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: If the Commissioner decides to serve an enforcement notice on a data user in consequence of an investigation, the Commissioner may serve the notice at the same time when informing the data user of the information relating to the investigation under subsection (2). (Added 18 of 2012 s. 26)

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commissioner has completed an investigation initiated by a complaint, he shall, in such manner and at such time as he thinks fit, inform the complainant of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the result of the investigation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any recommendations made to the relevant data user under subsection (2)(b);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any report arising from the investigation that he proposes to publish under section 48;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any comments made by or on behalf of the relevant data user on any such recommendations or report;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: whether or not he has served, or has decided to serve, an enforcement notice on the relevant data user in consequence of the investigation;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: if the Commissioner has not so served, and has decided not to so serve, such enforcement notice, his right to object thereto under subsection (4); and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: such other comments arising from the investigation as he thinks fit to make.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: Subsection (3) does not apply if the complainant has withdrawn the complaint. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 26)

subsection.leadIn: The complainant (or, if the complainant is a relevant person, the individual in respect of whom the complainant is such a person, or either) may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Board against a decision of the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the effect that he has not served, and has decided not to serve, an enforcement notice on the relevant data user in consequence of the investigation concerned; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of which the complainant was informed in the notice concerned under subsection (3) served on him.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), the Commissioner may, after completing an inspection where section 36(b) is applicable, publish a report—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: setting out any recommendations arising from the inspection that the Commissioner thinks fit to make relating to the promotion of compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance, in particular the data protection principles, by the class of data users to which the relevant data user belongs; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in such manner as he thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), the Commissioner may, after completing an investigation and if he is of the opinion that it is in the public interest to do so, publish a report—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: setting out—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the result of the investigation;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any recommendations arising from the investigation that the Commissioner thinks fit to make relating to the promotion of compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance, in particular the data protection principles, by the class of data users to which the relevant data user belongs; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: such other comments arising from the investigation as he thinks fit to make; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in such manner as he thinks fit.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), a report published under subsection (1) or (2) shall be so framed as to prevent the identity of any individual being ascertained from it. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 27)

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) shall not apply to any individual who is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner or a prescribed officer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the relevant data user.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Cases in which sections 47 and 48 shall not apply
section.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner has completed an investigation (and whether or not the investigation was initiated by a complaint);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the result of the investigation is that the act or practice the subject of the investigation is not a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance because of an exemption under Part 8; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the interest protected by that exemption would be likely to be prejudiced if sections 47 and 48 applied in relation to the investigation,

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: those sections shall not apply in relation to the investigation; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.leadIn: the Commissioner shall, in such manner and at such time as he thinks fit—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: inform the relevant data user of the result of the investigation and such other comments arising from the investigation as he thinks fit;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: if the investigation was initiated by a complaint, inform the complainant that the result of the investigation is that he is satisfied that the act or practice the subject of the investigation is not a contravention of a requirement under this Ordinance (or words to the like effect).

subsection.content: If, following the completion of an investigation, the Commissioner is of the opinion that the relevant data user is contravening or has contravened a requirement under this Ordinance, the Commissioner may serve on the data user a notice in writing, directing the data user to remedy and, if appropriate, prevent any recurrence of the contravention. (Replaced 18 of 2012 s. 28)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: An enforcement notice under subsection (1) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state that the Commissioner is of the opinion referred to in subsection (1) and the reason for that opinion;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: specify—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the requirement which, in the opinion of the Commissioner, is being or has been contravened; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the act or omission that constitutes the contravention;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the steps that the data user must take (including ceasing any act or practice) to remedy and, if appropriate, prevent any recurrence of the contravention;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: specify the date on or before which the steps must be taken; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: be accompanied by a copy of this section. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 28)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: The date specified in subsection (1A)(d) must be a date which is not earlier than the expiry of the period specified in subsection (7) within which an appeal against the notice may be made. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 28)

In deciding whether to serve an enforcement notice the Commissioner shall consider whether the contravention to which the notice relates has caused or is likely to cause damage or distress to any individual who is the data subject of any personal data to which the contravention relates. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 28)

subsection.leadIn: The steps specified in an enforcement notice to remedy and, if appropriate, prevent any recurrence of any contravention to which the notice relates may be framed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to any extent by reference to any approved code of practice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so as to afford the relevant data user a choice between different ways of remedying and, if appropriate, preventing any recurrence of the contravention. (Replaced 18 of 2012 s. 28)

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (5), the period specified in an enforcement notice for taking the steps specified in it shall not expire before the end of the period specified in subsection (7) within which an appeal against the notice may be made and, if such an appeal is made, those steps need not be taken pending the determination or withdrawal of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner is of the opinion that by reason of special circumstances the steps specified in an enforcement notice should be taken as a matter of urgency—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he may include a statement to that effect in the notice together with the reasons why he is of that opinion;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where such a statement is so included, subsection (4) shall not apply but the notice shall not require those steps to be taken before the end of the period of 7 days beginning with the date on which the notice was served.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may cancel an enforcement notice by notice in writing served on the relevant data user.
An appeal may be made to the Administrative Appeals Board against an enforcement notice by the relevant data user not later than 14 days after the notice was served.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: forms an opinion referred to in subsection (1) in respect of the relevant data user at any time before the completion of an investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is also of the opinion that, by reason of special circumstances, an enforcement notice should be served on the relevant data user as a matter of urgency,

subsection.continued: he may so serve such notice notwithstanding that the investigation has not been completed and, in any such case—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the Commissioner shall, without prejudice to any other matters to be included in such notice, specify in the notice the reasons as to why he is of the opinion referred to in paragraph (b); and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the other provisions of this Ordinance (including this section) shall be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: A data user who contravenes an enforcement notice commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: on a first conviction—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the offence continues after the conviction, to a daily penalty of $1,000; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: on a second or subsequent conviction—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the offence continues after the conviction, to a daily penalty of $2,000.

subsection.content: In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (1), it is a defence for the data user charged to show that the data user exercised all due diligence to comply with the enforcement notice.

subsection.leadIn: A data user who, having complied with an enforcement notice, intentionally does the same act or makes the same omission in contravention of the requirement under this Ordinance, as specified in the enforcement notice under section 50(1A)(b), commits an offence and is liable on conviction—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the offence continues after the conviction, to a daily penalty of $1,000.

section.name: s50B
section.heading: Offences relating to failure to comply with requirements of Commissioner etc.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without lawful excuse, obstructs, hinders or resists the Commissioner or a prescribed officer in performing the functions or exercising the powers of the Commissioner or the officer under this Part;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without lawful excuse, fails to comply with any lawful requirement of the Commissioner or a prescribed officer under this Part; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in the course of the performance or exercise by the Commissioner or a prescribed officer of functions or powers under this Part—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: makes to the Commissioner or the officer a statement which the person knows to be false or does not believe to be true; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: otherwise knowingly misleads the Commissioner or the officer.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Interpretation
section.content: Where any personal data is exempt from any provision of this Ordinance by virtue of this Part, then, in respect of that data and to the extent of that exemption, that provision neither confers any right nor imposes any requirement on any person, and the other provisions of this Ordinance which relate (whether directly or indirectly) to that provision shall be construed accordingly.

subsection.content: Personal data held by a court, a magistrate or a judicial officer in the course of performing judicial functions is exempt from the provisions of the data protection principles and Parts 4 and 5 and sections 36 and 38(b).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: judicial officer (司法人員) has the same meaning given by section 2 of the Judicial Officers Recommendation Commission Ordinance (Cap. 92).

section.name: s52
section.heading: Domestic purposes
section.leadIn: Personal data held by an individual and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: concerned only with the management of his personal, family or household affairs; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: so held only for recreational purposes,

section.continued: is exempt from the provisions of the data protection principles, Parts 4 and 5 and sections 36 and 38(b).

section.name: s53
section.heading: Employment—staff planning
section.leadIn: Personal data which consists of information relevant to any staff planning proposal to— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fill any series of positions of employment which are presently, or may become, unfilled; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cease any group of individuals’ employment,

section.continued: is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b).

subsection.leadIn: Personal data—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: held by a data user—

subparagraph.content: immediately before the appointed day;
who is the employer of the data subject; and
relating to the employment of the subject; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provided by an individual on the implicit or explicit condition that the subject would not have access to the data,
