subsection.continued: is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b) until the expiration of 7 years immediately following the enactment of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Personal data—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to which subsection (1)(a) applies; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: held by a data user—

subparagraph.content: but not so held at any time before the appointed day;
who is the employer of the data subject; and
relating to the employment of the subject,

subsection.continued: is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b) until 1 July 1996.

subsection.content: Personal data the subject of a relevant process is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b) until the completion of that process. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: completion (完成), in relation to a relevant process, means the making of the determination concerned referred to in paragraph (a) of the definition of relevant process;

def.name: RelevantProcess
def.leadIn: relevant process (有關程序)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: subject to paragraph (b), means any process whereby personal data is considered by one or more persons for the purpose of determining, or enabling there to be determined— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the suitability, eligibility or qualifications of the data subject for—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: employment or appointment to office;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: promotion in employment or office or continuance in employment or office;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: removal from employment or office; or

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: the awarding of contracts, awards (including academic and professional qualifications), scholarships, honours or other benefits;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whether any contract, award (including academic and professional qualifications), scholarship, honour or benefit relating to the data subject should be continued, modified or cancelled; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: whether any disciplinary action should be taken against the data subject for a breach of the terms of his employment or appointment to office;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: does not include any such process where no appeal, whether under an Ordinance or otherwise, may be made against any such determination.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Personal references
section.leadIn: Personal data held by a data user which consists of a personal reference— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: given by an individual other than in the ordinary course of his occupation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: relevant to another individual’s suitability or otherwise to fill any position of employment or office which is presently, or may become, unfilled,

section.continued: is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b)— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: in any case, unless the individual referred to in paragraph (a) has informed the data user in writing that he has no objection to the reference being seen by the individual referred to in paragraph (b) (or words to the like effect); or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: in the case of a reference given on or after the day on which this section comes into operation, until the individual referred to in paragraph (b) has been informed in writing that he has been accepted or rejected to fill that position or office (or words to the like effect),

section.name: s57
section.heading: Security, etc. in respect of Hong Kong

subsection.content: Personal data held by or on behalf of the Government for the purposes of safeguarding security, defence or international relations in respect of Hong Kong is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b) where the application of those provisions to the data would be likely to prejudice any of the matters referred to in this subsection. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: Personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 in any case in which— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the use of the data is for any of the purposes referred to in subsection (1) (and whether or not the data is held for any of those purposes); and (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the application of those provisions in relation to such use would be likely to prejudice any of the matters referred to in that subsection,

subsection.continued: and in any proceedings against any person for a contravention of any of those provisions it shall be a defence to show that he had reasonable grounds for believing that failure to so use the data would have been likely to prejudice any of those matters.

subsection.content: Any question whether an exemption under subsection (1) is or at any time was required in respect of any personal data may be determined by the Chief Executive or Chief Secretary for Administration; and a certificate signed by the Chief Executive or Chief Secretary for Administration certifying that the exemption is or at any time was so required shall be evidence of that fact. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 34 of 1999 s. 3)

For the purposes of subsection (2), a certificate signed by the Chief Executive or Chief Secretary for Administration certifying that personal data is or has been used for any purpose referred to in subsection (1) shall be evidence of that fact. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 34 of 1999 s. 3; 18 of 2012 s. 2)

The Chief Executive or Chief Secretary for Administration may, in a certificate referred to in subsection (3) or (4), in respect of the personal data to which the certificate relates and for the reasons specified in that certificate, direct the Commissioner not to carry out an inspection or investigation and, in any such case, the Commissioner shall comply with the direction. (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997; 34 of 1999 s. 3)
A document purporting to be a certificate referred to in subsection (3) or (4) shall be received in evidence and, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, shall be deemed to be such a certificate.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: international relations (國際關係) includes relations with any international organization;

security (保安) includes the prevention or preclusion of persons (including persons detained in accordance with the provisions of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115)) entering and remaining in Hong Kong who do not have the right to enter and remain in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: Personal data held for the purposes of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the prevention or detection of crime;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the apprehension, prosecution or detention of offenders;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the assessment or collection of any tax or duty;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the prevention, preclusion or remedying (including punishment) of unlawful or seriously improper conduct, or dishonesty or malpractice, by persons;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the prevention or preclusion of significant financial loss arising from—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any imprudent business practices or activities of persons; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: unlawful or seriously improper conduct, or dishonesty or malpractice, by persons;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: ascertaining whether the character or activities of the data subject are likely to have a significantly adverse impact on any thing—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to which the discharge of statutory functions by the data user relates; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: which relates to the discharge of functions to which this paragraph applies by virtue of subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: discharging functions to which this paragraph applies by virtue of subsection (3),

subsection.continued: is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b) where the application of those provisions to the data would be likely to— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 31)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: prejudice any of the matters referred to in this subsection; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: directly or indirectly identify the person who is the source of the data.

def.name: Tax
def.leadIn: In subsection (1)(c), tax (稅項) includes any tax of a territory outside Hong Kong if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: arrangements having effect under section 49(1A) of the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112) are made with the government of that territory; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that tax is the subject of a provision of the arrangements that requires disclosure of information concerning tax of that territory. (Added 1 of 2010 s. 9)

subsection.leadIn: Personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 in any case in which— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 31)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the use of the data is for any of the purposes referred to in subsection (1) (and whether or not the data is held for any of those purposes); and (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 31)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the application of those provisions in relation to such use would be likely to prejudice any of the matters referred to in that subsection,

subsection.continued: and in any proceedings against any person for a contravention of any of those provisions it shall be a defence to show that he had reasonable grounds for believing that failure to so use the data would have been likely to prejudice any of those matters.

subsection.leadIn: Paragraphs (f)(ii) and (g) of subsection (1) apply to any functions of a financial regulator—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for protecting members of the public against financial loss arising from—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: dishonesty, incompetence, malpractice or seriously improper conduct by persons—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: concerned in the provision of banking, insurance, investment or other financial services;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: concerned in the management of companies;

subparagraph.name: BA
subparagraph.content: concerned in the administration of provident fund schemes registered under the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 485); (Added 4 of 1998 s. 14)

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: concerned in the management of occupational retirement schemes within the meaning of the Occupational Retirement Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 426); or

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: who are shareholders in companies; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the conduct of discharged or undischarged bankrupts;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for maintaining or promoting the general stability or effective working of any of the systems which provide any of the services referred to in paragraph (a)(i)(A); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specified for the purposes of this subsection in a notice under subsection (4).

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (3), the Chief Executive may, by notice in the Gazette, specify a function of a financial regulator. (Amended 34 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: It is hereby declared that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subsection (3) shall not operate to prejudice the generality of the operation of paragraphs (a), (b), (c), (d) and (f)(i) of subsection (1) in relation to a financial regulator;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notice under subsection (4) is subsidiary legislation.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: Crime
def.leadIn: crime (罪行) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under the laws of Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if personal data is held or used in connection with legal or law enforcement cooperation between Hong Kong and a place outside Hong Kong, an offence under the laws of that place;

subsection.def: offender (犯罪者) means a person who commits a crime. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 31)

section.name: s58A
section.heading: Protected product and relevant records under Interception of Communications and Surveillance Ordinance

subsection.content: A personal data system is exempt from the provisions of this Ordinance to the extent that it is used by a data user for the collection, holding, processing or use of personal data which is, or is contained in, protected product or relevant records.
Personal data which is, or is contained in, protected product or relevant records is exempt from the provisions of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: protected product (受保護成果) has the meaning assigned to it by section 2(1) of the Interception of Communications and Surveillance Ordinance (Cap. 589);

def.name: RelevantRecords
def.leadIn: relevant records (有關紀錄) means documents and records relating to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any application for the issue or renewal of any prescribed authorization or device retrieval warrant under the Interception of Communications and Surveillance Ordinance (Cap. 589); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any prescribed authorization or device retrieval warrant issued or renewed under that Ordinance (including anything done pursuant to or in relation to such prescribed authorization or device retrieval warrant).

subsection.leadIn: Personal data relating to the physical or mental health of the data subject is exempt from the provisions of either or both of— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 32)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: data protection principle 3,

subsection.continued: in any case in which the application of those provisions to the data would be likely to cause serious harm to the physical or mental health of—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the data subject; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: any other individual.

subsection.leadIn: Personal data relating to the identity or location of a data subject is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 if the application of those provisions to the data would be likely to cause serious harm to the physical or mental health of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the data subject; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other individual. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 32)

section.name: s59A
section.heading: Care and guardianship of minors
section.leadIn: Personal data in relation to a minor transferred or disclosed by the Hong Kong Police Force or Customs and Excise Department to a relevant person of the minor is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the purpose of the transfer or disclosure is to facilitate the relevant person to exercise proper care and guardianship of the minor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the transfer or disclosure is in the interest of the minor; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the application of those provisions in relation to such transfer or disclosure would be likely to prejudice the exercise of proper care and guardianship of the minor by the relevant person or the interest of the minor.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Legal professional privilege
section.content: Personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b) if the data consists of information in respect of which a claim to legal professional privilege could be maintained in law.

subsection.content: If, as a result of complying with a request under a provision of data protection principle 6 or section 18(1)(b) in relation to any personal data, a data user might be incriminated in any proceedings for any offence other than an offence under this Ordinance, the data is exempt from that provision or section.

Information disclosed by a data user in compliance with a request under a provision of data protection principle 6 or section 18(1)(b) is not admissible against the data user in any proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance.

section.name: s60B
section.heading: Legal proceedings etc.
section.leadIn: Personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 if the use of the data is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: required or authorized by or under any enactment, by any rule of law or by an order of a court in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: required in connection with any legal proceedings in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: required for establishing, exercising or defending legal rights in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: Personal data held by a data user—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whose business, or part of whose business, consists of a news activity; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: solely for the purpose of that activity (or any directly related activity),

subsection.continued: is exempt from the provisions of— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: data protection principle 6 and sections 18(1)(b) and 38(i) unless and until the data is published or broadcast (wherever and by whatever means);

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: sections 36 and 38(b).

subsection.leadIn: Personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 in any case in which— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the use of the data consists of disclosing the data to a data user referred to in subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such disclosure is made by a person who has reasonable grounds to believe (and reasonably believes) that the publishing or broadcasting (wherever and by whatever means) of the data (and whether or not it is published or broadcast) is in the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: NewsActivity
def.leadIn: news activity (新聞活動) means any journalistic activity and includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: gathering of news;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: preparation or compiling of articles or programmes concerning news; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: observations on news or current affairs,

paragraph.continued: for the purpose of dissemination to the public; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the dissemination to the public of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any article or programme of or concerning news; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: observations on news or current affairs.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Statistics and research
section.leadIn: Personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 where— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the data is to be used for preparing statistics or carrying out research;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the data is not to be used for any other purpose; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the resulting statistics or results of the research are not made available in a form which identifies the data subjects or any of them.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Exemption from section 18(1)(a)
section.content: Where a data access request relates to personal data which is or, if the data existed, would be exempt from section 18(1)(b) by virtue of section 57 or 58, then the data is also exempt from section 18(1)(a) if the interest protected by that exemption would be likely to be prejudiced by the disclosure of the existence or non-existence of that data.

subsection.content: Personal data which consists of information showing that an identifiable individual was, or may have been, born in consequence of a reproductive technology procedure within the meaning of the Human Reproductive Technology Ordinance (Cap. 561) is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6 and section 18(1)(b) except so far as its disclosure under those provisions is made in accordance with section 33 of that Ordinance.

Where a data access request relates to personal data which is or, if the data existed, would be exempt from section 18(1)(b) by virtue of subsection (1), then the data is also exempt from section 18(1)(a) if the interest protected by that exemption would be likely to be prejudiced by the disclosure of the existence or non-existence of the data.

subsection.leadIn: Personal data transferred or disclosed by a data user for the purpose of a due diligence exercise to be conducted in connection with a proposed business transaction that involves—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a transfer of the business or property of, or any shares in, the data user;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a change in the shareholdings of the data user; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an amalgamation of the data user with another body,

subsection.continued: is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 if each of the conditions specified in subsection (2) is satisfied.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the personal data transferred or disclosed is not more than necessary for the purpose of the due diligence exercise;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: goods, facilities or services which are the same as or similar to those provided by the data user to the data subject are to be provided to the data subject, on completion of the proposed business transaction, by a party to the transaction or a new body formed as a result of the transaction;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it is not practicable to obtain the prescribed consent of the data subject for the transfer or disclosure.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not apply if the primary purpose of the proposed business transaction is the transfer, disclosure or provision for gain of the personal data.

subsection.leadIn: If a data user transfers or discloses personal data to a person for the purpose of a due diligence exercise to be conducted in connection with a proposed business transaction described in subsection (1), the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must only use the data for that purpose; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must, as soon as practicable after the completion of the due diligence exercise—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: return the personal data to the data user; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: destroy any record of the personal data that is kept by the person.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (4) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: due diligence exercise (盡職審查), in relation to a proposed business transaction, means the examination of the subject matter of the transaction to enable a party to decide whether to proceed with the transaction;

def.name: ProvisionForGain
def.leadIn: provision for gain (為得益而提供), in relation to personal data, means provision of the data in return for money or other property, irrespective of whether—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the return is contingent on any condition; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person who provides the data retains any control over the use of the data.

subsection.leadIn: Personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 1(3) and data protection principle 3 if the application of those provisions to the data would be likely to prejudice any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identifying an individual who is reasonably suspected to be, or is, involved in a life-threatening situation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: informing the individual’s family members or relevant persons of the individual’s involvement in the life-threatening situation; (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 5)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the carrying out of emergency rescue operations or provision of emergency relief services.

section.name: s63D
section.heading: Transfer of records to Government Records Service
section.leadIn: Personal data contained in records that are transferred to the Government Records Service is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 3 when the records are used by the Government Records Service solely for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appraising the records to decide whether they are to be preserved; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: organizing and preserving the records.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Offences for disclosing personal data without consent

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person discloses any personal data of a data subject which was obtained from a data user without the data user’s consent, with an intent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to obtain gain in money or other property, whether for the benefit of the person or another person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to cause loss in money or other property to the data subject.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years. (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person discloses any personal data of a data subject without the relevant consent of the data subject—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with an intent to cause any specified harm to the data subject or any family member of the data subject; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being reckless as to whether any specified harm would be, or would likely be, caused to the data subject or any family member of the data subject. (Added 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3B
subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3A) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years. (Added 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3C
subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the person discloses any personal data of a data subject without the relevant consent of the data subject—

subparagraph.content: with an intent to cause any specified harm to the data subject or any family member of the data subject; or
being reckless as to whether any specified harm would be, or would likely be, caused to the data subject or any family member of the data subject; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure causes any specified harm to the data subject or any family member of the data subject. (Added 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.name: 3D
subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3C) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years. (Added 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings for an offence under subsection (1), (3A) or (3C), it is a defence for the person charged to establish that— (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 6)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person reasonably believed that the disclosure was necessary for the purpose of preventing or detecting crime;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure was required or authorized by or under any enactment, by any rule of law or by an order of a court;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the person reasonably believed that the disclosure was made with— (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subparagraph.content: for an offence under subsection (1)—the data user’s consent; or
for an offence under subsection (3A) or (3C)—the relevant consent of the data subject; or (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 6)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: disclosed the personal data solely for the purpose of a lawful news activity as defined by section 61(3) or a directly related activity; and (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: had reasonable grounds to believe that the publishing or broadcasting of the personal data was in the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: A person is taken to have established a matter that needs to be established for the purpose of a defence under subsection (4) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue with respect to the matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt. (Added 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant consent (相關同意), in relation to a data subject, means—(a)if the data subject is an individual described in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of the definition of relevant person in section 2(1)—the consent of a relevant person of the individual on the individual’s behalf; or(b)otherwise—the consent of the data subject;

specified harm (指明傷害), in relation to a person, means—(a)harassment, molestation, pestering, threat or intimidation to the person;(b)bodily harm or psychological harm to the person;(c)harm causing the person reasonably to be concerned for the person’s safety or well-being; or(d)damage to the property of the person. (Added 32 of 2021 s. 6)

subsection.content: A data user who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes any requirement under this Ordinance commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a contravention of a data protection principle;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a contravention that constitutes an offence under section 14(11), 14A(6), (7) or (8), 15(4A) or (7), 18(5), 22(4), 31(4), 32(5), 44(10), 46(11), 50A(1) or (3), 50B(1), 63B(5) or 64(1), (3A) or (3C); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a contravention of any requirement under Part 6A or 9A. (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 7)

subsection.content: A prosecution for a summary offence under this Ordinance may only be started before the end of 2 years after the date on which the offence is committed.

statutoryNote.content: This replaces the time limit under section 26 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: summary offence (簡易程序罪行) means an offence triable summarily only.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may prosecute in the name of the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under section 64(1) or (3A), 66E(1) or (5), 66I(1) or 66O(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence of conspiracy to commit such an offence.

subsection.content: Any offence prosecuted under subsection (1) must be tried before a magistrate as an offence that is triable summarily.
This section does not derogate from the powers of the Secretary for Justice in respect of the prosecution of criminal offences.

Any act done or practice engaged in by a person in the course of his employment shall be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as done or engaged in by his employer as well as by him, whether or not it was done or engaged in with the employer’s knowledge or approval.

Any act done or practice engaged in by a person as agent for another person with the authority (whether express or implied, and whether precedent or subsequent) of that other person shall be treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as done or engaged in by that other person as well as by him.

In proceedings brought under this Ordinance against any person in respect of an act or practice alleged to have been done or engaged in, as the case may be, by an employee of his it shall be a defence for that person to prove that he took such steps as were practicable to prevent the employee from doing that act or engaging in that practice, or from doing or engaging in, in the course of his employment, acts or practices, as the case may be, of that description.
For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that this section shall not apply for the purposes of any criminal proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), an individual who suffers damage by reason of a contravention—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of a requirement under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by a data user; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: which relates, whether in whole or in part, to personal data of which that individual is the data subject,

subsection.continued: shall be entitled to compensation from that data user for that damage.

subsection.content: For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that damage referred to in subsection (1) may be or include injury to feelings.

subsection.leadIn: In any proceedings brought against any person by virtue of this section it shall be a defence to show that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he had taken such care as in all the circumstances was reasonably required to avoid the contravention concerned; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any case where the contravention concerned occurred because the personal data concerned was inaccurate, the data accurately record data received or obtained by the data user concerned from the data subject or a third party. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 38)

subsection.content: Where an individual suffers damage referred to in subsection (1) by reason of a contravention referred to in that subsection which occurred because the personal data concerned was inaccurate, then no compensation shall be payable under that subsection in respect of so much of that damage that has occurred at any time before the expiration of 1 year immediately following the day on which this section commences. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 38)

Proceedings brought by an individual in reliance on subsection (1) are to be brought in the District Court but all such remedies are obtainable in those proceedings as would be obtainable in the Court of First Instance. (Added 18 of 2012 s. 38)

section.name: s66A
section.heading: Help for aggrieved persons in obtaining information, etc.

subsection.leadIn: With a view to helping a person (the person aggrieved) to decide whether to institute proceedings under section 66 and, if the person does so, to formulate and present his or her case in the most effective manner, the Commissioner may prescribe—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: forms by which the person aggrieved may question the respondent on the respondent’s reasons for doing any relevant act, or on any other matter which is or may be relevant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: forms by which the respondent may, if he or she so wishes, reply to any questions.

subsection.leadIn: If the person aggrieved questions the respondent (whether or not in accordance with a form referred to in subsection (1))—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the question and any reply by the respondent (whether or not in accordance with such a form) are, subject to subsections (3), (4) and (5), admissible as evidence in the proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it appears to the District Court that the respondent, deliberately and without reasonable excuse, omitted to reply within a reasonable period or that the respondent’s reply is evasive or equivocal, the Court may draw any inference from that fact it considers just and equitable to draw.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe the period within which questions must be served in order to be admissible under subsection (2)(a); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribe the manner in which a question and any reply by the respondent may be served.

subsection.content: Rules under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336) may empower the District Court entertaining a claim under section 66 to determine, before the date fixed for the hearing of the claim, whether a question or reply is admissible under this section or not.

This section is without prejudice to any other enactment or rule of law regulating interlocutory and preliminary matters in proceedings before the District Court, and has effect subject to any enactment or rule of law regulating the admissibility of evidence in such proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

section.name: s66B
section.heading: Commissioner may grant assistance in respect of proceedings

subsection.content: A person who may institute proceedings to seek compensation under section 66 may make an application to the Commissioner for assistance in respect of those proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner must consider an application under subsection (1) and may grant it if the Commissioner thinks fit to do so, in particular if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the case raises a question of principle; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is unreasonable, having regard to the complexity of the case or the applicant’s position in relation to the respondent or another person involved or any other matter, to expect the applicant to deal with the case unaided.

subsection.leadIn: Assistance by the Commissioner under this section may include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: giving advice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arranging for the giving of advice or assistance by a solicitor or counsel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: arranging for representation by any person, including all such assistance as is usually given by a solicitor or counsel in the steps preliminary or incidental to any proceedings, or in arriving at or giving effect to a compromise to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other form of assistance which the Commissioner may consider appropriate.

subsection.content: Subsection (3)(c) does not affect the law and practice regulating the descriptions of persons who may appear in, conduct, defend and address a court in, any proceedings except to the extent permitted under rules made in accordance with section 73F of the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336).

subsection.leadIn: If expenses are incurred by the Commissioner in providing the applicant with assistance under this section, the recovery of those expenses (as taxed or assessed in such manner as may be prescribed by relevant rules) constitutes a first charge for the benefit of the Commissioner—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on any costs or expenses which are payable to the applicant by any other person (whether by virtue of a judgment or order of the District Court or an agreement or otherwise) in respect of the matter in connection with which the assistance is given; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the applicant’s rights (so far as those rights relate to any costs or expenses) under any compromise or settlement arrived at in connection with that matter to avoid or bring to an end any proceedings.

subsection.content: The charge created by subsection (5) is subject to any charge under the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) and to any provision in that Ordinance for payment of any sum into the Supplementary Legal Aid Fund established under that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant rules (《法院規則》) means any rules made under the District Court Ordinance (Cap. 336);
respondent (答辯人) includes a prospective respondent.

part.name: P9A
part.heading: Offences under Section 64 and Related Matters—Investigations and Enforcement Powers

section.name: s66C
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 9A
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: material (材料) means any document, information or thing;
specified investigation (指明調查) means an investigation into an offence under section 64(1), (3A) or (3C), 66E(1) or (5), 66I(1) or 66O(1).

section.name: s66D
section.heading: Commissioner’s powers to require materials and assistance

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if the Commissioner reasonably suspects that, in relation to a specified investigation, a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has or may have possession or control of any material relevant to that investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may otherwise be able to assist the Commissioner in relation to that investigation.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may, by written notice given to the person, require the person—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: to answer any written question relating to a matter that the Commissioner reasonably believes to be relevant to the specified investigation;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to make a statement relating to a matter that the Commissioner reasonably believes to be relevant to the specified investigation; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to give the Commissioner all the assistance that the Commissioner reasonably requires for the specified investigation.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (2) must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in the specified form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be signed by the Commissioner or a prescribed officer; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: indicate the subject matter and purpose of the specified investigation.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner may also specify in the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the time and place at which the material is to be provided; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the way and form in which it is to be provided.

subsection.leadIn: The power under subsection (2)(a) to require a person to provide material includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the material is recorded otherwise than in a legible form, the power to require the production of its copy—

subparagraph.content: in a visible and legible form; or
in a form from which it can readily be produced in a visible and legible form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the material is stored electronically, the power to require the person—

subparagraph.content: to give directions on the operation of the equipment containing the material; and
to provide the appropriate system for reducing the material into a written form on paper.

subsection.leadIn: The power under subsection (2)(a) to require a person to provide material includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the material is provided, the power—

subparagraph.content: to make copies of, or to take extracts from, the material;
to retain the material for a period reasonably required for the specified investigation; or
to require the person, or another person whom the Commissioner reasonably believes is able to do so, to give an explanation of, or further particulars about, the material; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the material is not provided, the power to require the person to state, to the best of the person’s knowledge and belief, where it is.

subsection.content: If the Commissioner exercises the power under subsection (2)(a) to require a person to provide the Commissioner with an electronic device, the power may only be exercised subject to section 66G.
A person commits an offence if the person fails to comply with a requirement of a notice given to the person under section 66D(2).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 1 year.

subsection.content: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (1) to establish that the person had a reasonable excuse for failing to comply with the requirement.

subsection.leadIn: A person is taken to have established that the person had a reasonable excuse referred to in subsection (3) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue that the person had such a reasonable excuse; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, with intent to defraud—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with a requirement of a notice given to the person under section 66D(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in purported compliance with such a requirement, provides any material, gives any answer, directions, explanation or particulars, or makes any statement, that is or are false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (5) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.content: A person is not excused from complying with a requirement of a notice given to the person under section 66D(2) only on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

section.name: s66F
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence in proceedings

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) applies if—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: the person claims, before giving or making the required matter, that it might so tend.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement, question and required matter are not admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings other than those in which the person is charged in respect of the required matter with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under section 66E(5); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence under Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200).

subsection.content: Subsection (2) does not apply if, in the criminal proceedings, evidence relating to the required matter is adduced, or a question relating to it is asked, by the person who gives or makes the required matter or on that person’s behalf.

On or before imposing a requirement on a person to give or make the required matter under section 66D(2), the Commissioner must ensure that the person is informed or reminded of the limitations imposed by subsection (2) on the admissibility in evidence of the requirement, question and required matter.

division.name: D3
division.heading: Powers Exercisable in relation to Premises, Electronic Devices and Suspected Offenders

section.name: s66G
section.heading: Powers exercisable in relation to premises and electronic devices

subsection.leadIn: If a magistrate is satisfied by information on oath by the Commissioner or any prescribed officer that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that an offence under section 64(1), (3A) or (3C), 66E(1) or (5), 66I(1) or 66O(1) has been, is being or is about to be committed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that—

subparagraph.content: there is in any premises any material that is or contains evidence for the purposes of a specified investigation; or
any material that is or contains evidence for the purposes of a specified investigation is stored in an electronic device,

subsection.continued: the magistrate may issue a warrant (warrant) authorizing the Commissioner or any prescribed officer, together with any person (whether or not a police officer) who may be necessary to assist the Commissioner or the prescribed officer so authorized, to exercise the powers referred to in subsection (2) or (3), as the case may be.

subsection.leadIn: The powers that may be exercised in relation to premises mentioned in subsection (1)(b)(i) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to enter and search the premises (by using any force that is reasonable in the circumstances if necessary);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to carry out the specified investigation in the premises; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to seize, remove and detain any material in the premises that the Commissioner or any prescribed officer reasonably suspects to be or to contain evidence for the purposes of the specified investigation.

subsection.leadIn: The powers that may be exercised in relation to an electronic device mentioned in subsection (1)(b)(ii) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to access the device;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to seize and detain the device;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to decrypt any material stored in the device;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to search for any material stored in the device that the Commissioner or any prescribed officer reasonably suspects to be or to contain evidence for the purposes of the specified investigation (relevant material);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to reproduce the relevant material in visible and legible form;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to reduce the relevant material into a written form on paper; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to make copies of, or take extracts from, the relevant material and take away such copies or extracts.

subsection.content: The warrant must be in the form set out in Part 3 of Schedule 6.
The warrant continues in force until the expiry of 14 days after the date on which it is issued.

When powers are exercised under the warrant, a specified person must, without charge, afford facilities and assistance reasonably required by the Commissioner or any prescribed officer for the purposes of the specified investigation.

When powers are exercised under the warrant, the Commissioner or any prescribed officer must produce the warrant for inspection by a specified person who questions the authority to exercise the powers.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner or any prescribed officer—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: is satisfied that a delay caused by an application for a warrant under subsection (1) is likely to defeat the purpose of accessing the device, or for any reason it is not reasonably practicable to make the application,

subsection.continued: the Commissioner or any prescribed officer may, without warrant, access the device.

subsection.content: Subsections (1) and (8) do not affect any power that may be exercised under the common law in relation to an electronic device by a person who has made an arrest (whether or not under section 66H).

In exercising the power under subsection (8), the Commissioner or prescribed officer must have regard to the safeguards under the common law to protect the privacy of a person in the circumstances in which a power to access an electronic device is exercised.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: premises (處所) has the meaning given by section 42(11);

specified person (指明人士) means—(a)in the case of a warrant being issued in relation to premises mentioned in subsection (1)(b)(i)—a person in the premises; or(b)in the case of a warrant being issued in relation to an electronic device mentioned in subsection (1)(b)(ii)—a person in possession or control of the device.

section.name: s66H
section.heading: Powers to stop, search and arrest persons

subsection.content: An authorized officer may, without warrant, stop, search and arrest any person whom the officer reasonably suspects of having committed an offence under section 64(1), (3A) or (3C), 66E(1) or (5), 66I(1) or 66O(1).

If any person resists, or attempts to evade, a search or arrest effected under subsection (1), the authorized officer may use any force that is reasonable in the circumstances to effect the search or arrest.

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer has arrested a person (arrested person) under subsection (1), the officer may search for and take possession of any thing that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be found on the arrested person or in or about the place at which the person has been arrested; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the officer reasonably suspects—

subparagraph.content: is related to the offence for which the person has been arrested; or
may throw light on the character or activities of the person.

subsection.leadIn: The authorized officer must take the arrested person to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an office of the Commissioner for further inquiries; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a police station to be dealt with in accordance with the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232).

subsection.leadIn: The authorized officer may require the arrested person to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the person’s name and correspondence address; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: produce the person’s proof of identity for inspection.

subsection.content: The arrested person must not be detained for more than 48 hours after the time the person is arrested without being charged and brought before a magistrate.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: authorized officer (獲授權人員) means—(a)the Commissioner; or(b)a person authorized by the Commissioner for the purposes of this section;
proof of identity (身分證明文件) has the meaning given by section 17B(1) of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115).

section.name: s66I
section.heading: Offence in relation to sections 66G and 66H

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if, when any power is being exercised under section 66G or 66H, the person, without lawful excuse, obstructs, hinders or resists—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prescribed officer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person authorized by the Commissioner for the purposes of section 66H; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person assisting the Commissioner or a prescribed officer.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: In criminal proceedings for an offence under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the burden of establishing that a person has a lawful excuse referred to in subsection (1) lies on the person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person is taken to have established that the person had such a lawful excuse if—

subparagraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue that the person had such a lawful excuse; and
the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s66J
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 4 of Part 9A
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: cessation action (停止披露行動)—see section 66L;
cessation notice (停止披露通知) means a notice served under section 66M(1) or (2);
subject message (標的訊息) means a written message or electronic message by means of which a subject disclosure is made (whether or not the message exists in Hong Kong);
written message (書面訊息) includes—(a)a text or image message in writing; and(b)a message in writing combining text and images.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Division, a disclosure (whether or not in Hong Kong) of personal data of a data subject by a person is a subject disclosure if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: when the disclosure is made, the data subject—

subparagraph.content: is a Hong Kong resident; or
is present in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person discloses the personal data without the relevant consent of the data subject—

subparagraph.content: with an intent to cause any specified harm to the data subject or any family member of the data subject; or
being reckless as to whether any specified harm would be, or would likely be, caused to the data subject or any family member of the data subject.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant consent (相關同意) has the meaning given by section 64(6);
specified harm (指明傷害) has the meaning given by section 64(6).

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Division, a cessation action, in relation to a subject message, is any action to cease or restrict the subject disclosure made by means of the message, including the removal of the message.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (1), a cessation action, in relation to a subject message that is an electronic message, includes an action to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: remove the message from the electronic platform on which the message is published (relevant platform);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: cease or restrict access by any person to—

subparagraph.content: the message via the relevant platform;
the part of the relevant platform on which the message is published; or
the whole of the relevant platform; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: discontinue the hosting service for—

subparagraph.content: the part of the relevant platform on which the message is published; or
the whole of the relevant platform.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: access (接達) includes—(a)access that is subject to a pre-condition (including the use of a password);(b)access by way of push technology; and(c)access by way of a standing request;
carriage service (傳輸服務) means a service for carrying communications by means of guided or unguided electromagnetic energy or both;
electronic platform (電子平台) means a platform for intermediary service that is provided in an electronic system;Example—(a)a website; and(b)an online application.

intermediary service (中介服務) means—(a)a service that allows end-users to access materials originating from third parties through a carriage service;(b)a service of transmitting such materials to end-users through a carriage service; or(c)a service of displaying, to an end-user who uses the service to make a search through a carriage service, an index of search results, each of which links that end-user to content hosted or stored at a location that is separate from the location of the index of search results.

subsection.leadIn: If the Commissioner has reasonable ground to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is a subject message; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a Hong Kong person is able to take a cessation action (whether or not in Hong Kong) in relation to the message,

subsection.continued: the Commissioner may serve a written notice on the person directing the person to take the cessation action.

subsection.leadIn: In addition, if the Commissioner has reasonable ground to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is a subject message that is an electronic message; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a non-Hong Kong service provider is able to take a cessation action (whether or not in Hong Kong) in relation to the message,

subsection.continued: the Commissioner may serve a written notice on the provider directing the provider to take the cessation action.

subsection.leadIn: The cessation notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: state the Commissioner’s belief mentioned in subsection (1) or (2) and the ground for that belief;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: identify, in so far as reasonably practicable, the subject message in a way that is sufficient to enable the cessation action to be taken;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: specify the cessation action that must be taken;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: specify the date on or before which the cessation action must be taken; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: be accompanied by a copy of this section and sections 66N and 66O.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may cancel a cessation notice by serving a written notice on the person on whom the cessation notice is served.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Hong Kong person (香港人士) means—(a)an individual who is present in Hong Kong; or(b)a body of persons that—(i)is incorporated, established or registered in Hong Kong; or(ii)has a place of business in Hong Kong;
non-Hong Kong service provider (非港人服務提供者) means a person (not being a Hong Kong person) that has provided or is providing any service (whether or not in Hong Kong) to any Hong Kong person.

subsection.leadIn: Within 14 days after the date on which a cessation notice is served on a person, an appeal may be made to the Administrative Appeals Board against the notice by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person who is affected by the notice.

subsection.content: The appeal does not affect the operation of the cessation notice.

subsection.leadIn: If a person on whom a cessation notice is served contravenes the notice, the person commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on a first conviction—to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 2 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $1,000 for every day during which the offence continues; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on each subsequent conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine of $2,000 for every day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (1) in respect of a cessation notice to establish that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person had a reasonable excuse for contravening the cessation notice; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: without limiting paragraph (a), it was not reasonable to expect the person to comply with the cessation notice—

subparagraph.content: having regard to the nature, difficulty or complexity of the cessation action concerned;
because the technology necessary for complying with the cessation notice was not reasonably available to the person; or
because there was a risk of incurring substantial loss to, or otherwise substantially prejudicing the right of, a third party.

subsection.leadIn: The person is taken to have established a matter that needs to be established for the purpose of a defence under subsection (2) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue with respect to the matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s66P
section.heading: Immunity from civil liability
section.content: A person who complies with a cessation notice served on the person does not incur any civil liability, whether arising in contract, tort, equity or otherwise, to another person only because of that compliance.

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance (Court) may, on application by the Commissioner, grant an injunction, in any terms that the Court considers appropriate, if it is satisfied that a person (or any person falling within a category or description of persons) has engaged, is engaging or is likely to engage, in conduct that constitutes an offence under section 64(1), (3A) or (3C).

subsection.leadIn: The power of the Court to grant an injunction against a person (or any person falling within a category or description of persons) under subsection (1) may be exercised—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: whether or not the person has previously engaged in conduct of that kind; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether or not there is an imminent danger of substantial damage to any other person if the person engages in conduct of that kind.

subsection.content: If an application is made under subsection (1), the Court may, if it considers it desirable to do so, grant an interim injunction pending the determination of the application.
The Court may vary or discharge an injunction that it has granted under subsection (1) or (3).
The Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) apply in relation to an application made to, and an injunction granted by, the Court under this section.

section.name: s66R
section.heading: Commissioner and others to maintain secrecy

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), the following person (person concerned) must maintain secrecy in respect of any matter that comes to the person’s actual knowledge in performing the functions or exercising the powers under this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commissioner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a prescribed officer;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person authorized by the Commissioner for the purposes of section 66H; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person assisting the Commissioner or a prescribed officer.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not operate to prevent the person concerned from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (3), disclosing any matter to any person (including the Secretary for Justice and the Commissioner of Police) if the disclosure is necessary for the proper performance of the Commissioner’s functions or the proper exercise of the Commissioner’s powers under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: disclosing in the course of proceedings—

subparagraph.content: for an offence under this Ordinance; and
before any court or magistrate,

paragraph.continued: any matter relevant to those proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: reporting evidence of any crime to such authority as the person concerned considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the person concerned is one mentioned in subsection (1)(a), (b) or (c)—disclosing any matter referred to in subsection (1) that, in the opinion of the person concerned, may be a ground for a complaint by a person (prospective complainant) to the prospective complainant.

subsection.content: Section 46(7), (8), (9) and (10) applies in relation to the matter mentioned in subsection (1).
A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s66S
section.heading: Complainant to be informed of result of specified investigation
section.leadIn: After having completed a specified investigation initiated by a complaint, the Commissioner must, in the manner and at the time that the Commissioner considers appropriate, inform the complainant of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the result of that investigation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other matters arising from that investigation that the Commissioner considers appropriate.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Power of Commissioner to specify forms

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the Commissioner may specify the form of any document required under this Ordinance to be in the specified form and the form of such other documents required for the purposes of this Ordinance as he thinks fit.

The Commissioner’s power under subsection (1) shall be subject to any express requirement under this Ordinance for a form, whether specified or otherwise, to comply with that requirement, but that requirement shall not restrict the exercise of that power in respect of that form to the extent that, in the opinion of the Commissioner, his exercise of that power in respect of that form does not contravene that requirement.

subsection.leadIn: The Commissioner’s power under subsection (1) may be exercised in such a way as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: include in the specified form of any document referred to in that subsection a statutory declaration—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to be made by the person completing the form; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: as to whether the particulars contained in the form are true and correct to the best of that person’s knowledge and belief;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify 2 or more forms of any document referred to in that subsection, whether as alternatives, or to provide for particular circumstances or particular cases, as the Commissioner thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: A form specified under this section shall be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: completed in accordance with such directions and instructions as are specified in the form;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: accompanied by such documents as are specified in the form; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the completed form is required to be provided to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Commissioner;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: another person on behalf of the Commissioner; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: any other person,

paragraph.continued: so provided in the manner, if any, specified in the form.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Service of notices
section.leadIn: A notice (howsoever described) which is required to be served under this Ordinance, or which may be served under this Ordinance, on a person (howsoever described) shall, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, be deemed to be so served if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of an individual, it is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: delivered to him;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: left at his last known address for service, or at his last known place of residence or business, in Hong Kong or elsewhere; (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: sent by post to him at his last known address for service, or at his last known postal address, in Hong Kong or elsewhere; (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: sent by telex, facsimile transmission or other similar method to him at his last known address for service, or at his last known postal address, or at his last known place of residence or business, in Hong Kong or elsewhere; or (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 11)
sent by electronic mail transmission to the individual’s last known electronic mail address, or by any similar method of electronic transmission to the individual; (Added 32 of 2021 s. 11)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a company, it is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: given to or served on an officer of the company;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: left at the company’s last known address for service, or at its last known place of business, in Hong Kong or elsewhere; (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: sent by post to the company at its last known address for service, or at its last known postal address, in Hong Kong or elsewhere; (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 11)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: sent by telex, facsimile transmission or other similar method to the company at its last known address for service, or at its last known postal address, or at its last known place of business, in Hong Kong or elsewhere; or (Amended 32 of 2021 s. 11)
sent by electronic mail transmission to the company’s last known electronic mail address, or by any similar method of electronic transmission to the company; (Added 32 of 2021 s. 11)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a partnership, it is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: delivered, left or sent in accordance with paragraph (a) in respect of any partner who is an individual; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: given, served, left or sent in accordance with paragraph (b) in respect of any partner which is a company;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a person (attorney) holding a power of attorney under which the attorney is authorized to accept service in respect of another person, it is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: delivered, left or sent in accordance with paragraph (a) where the attorney is an individual;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: given, served, left or sent in accordance with paragraph (b) where the attorney is a company;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: delivered, left or sent in accordance with paragraph (a) in respect of any partner who is an individual where the attorney is a partnership; or

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: given, served, left or sent in accordance with paragraph (b) in respect of any partner which is a company where the attorney is a partnership.

subsection.content: The Commissioner may make regulations to prescribe the fees to be paid in respect of any matter, service or facility in respect of which a prescribed fee is payable to the Commissioner under this Ordinance.

The amount of any fee prescribed in regulations made under subsection (1) shall not be limited by reference to the amount of administrative or other costs incurred or likely to be incurred in relation to providing the matter, service or facility to which such fee relates, and different fees may be so prescribed for the same matter, service or facility in order to provide for particular circumstances or particular cases specified in the regulations.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs may make regulations for all or any of the following matters— (Amended L.N. 130 of 2007)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the particulars to be entered in the log book of a data user, including particulars referred to in section 27(2)(a), (b) and (c);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribing anything that is required or permitted to be prescribed under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Any regulations made under this section may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: empower the Commissioner to grant exemptions from the regulations, either generally or in a particular case;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make different provisions for different circumstances and provide for a particular case or class of case;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be made so as to apply only in such circumstances as are prescribed by the regulations.

subsection.content: Any regulations made under this section may prescribe offences in respect of contraventions of the regulations, and may provide for the imposition in respect of any such offence of a fine not exceeding level 3 and of imprisonment for a period not exceeding 2 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a daily penalty not exceeding $1,000.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Amendment of Schedules 2, 4 and 6
section.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by notice in the Gazette, amend Schedule 2, 4 or 6.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Use of forms in Schedule 6
section.content: A warrant required to be in a form set out in Schedule 6 may be in a form to the like effect with such modifications or variations as the circumstances may require.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Transitional provision for Personal Data (Privacy) (Amendment) Ordinance 2021

subsection.content: The pre-amended Ordinance continues to apply in relation to an offence under section 64(1) or (2) of the pre-amended Ordinance committed before the commencement date as if the 2021 Amendment Ordinance had not been enacted.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: 2021 Amendment Ordinance (《2021年修訂條例》) means the Personal Data (Privacy) (Amendment) Ordinance 2021 (32 of 2021);
*commencement date (生效日期) means the commencement date of the 2021 Amendment Ordinance;
pre-amended Ordinance (《原有條例》) means this Ordinance as in force immediately before the commencement date.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Principle 1—purpose and manner of collection of personal data

subsection.leadIn: Personal data shall not be collected unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the data is collected for a lawful purpose directly related to a function or activity of the data user who is to use the data;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (c), the collection of the data is necessary for or directly related to that purpose; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the data is adequate but not excessive in relation to that purpose.

subsection.leadIn: Personal data shall be collected by means which are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: lawful; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: fair in the circumstances of the case.

subsection.leadIn: Where the person from whom personal data is or is to be collected is the data subject, all practicable steps shall be taken to ensure that— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 40)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: he is explicitly or implicitly informed, on or before collecting the data, of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: whether it is obligatory or voluntary for him to supply the data; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: where it is obligatory for him to supply the data, the consequences for him if he fails to supply the data; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: he is explicitly informed—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: on or before collecting the data, of—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the purpose (in general or specific terms) for which the data is to be used; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the classes of persons to whom the data may be transferred; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: on or before first use of the data for the purpose for which it was collected, of— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 40)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: his rights to request access to and to request the correction of the data; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the name or job title, and address, of the individual who is to handle any such request made to the data user, (Replaced 18 of 2012 s. 40)

subsection.continued: unless to comply with the provisions of this subsection would be likely to prejudice the purpose for which the data was collected and that purpose is specified in Part 8 of this Ordinance as a purpose in relation to which personal data is exempt from the provisions of data protection principle 6.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Principle 2—accuracy and duration of retention of personal data

subsection.leadIn: All practicable steps shall be taken to ensure that—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: where there are reasonable grounds for believing that personal data is inaccurate having regard to the purpose (including any directly related purpose) for which the data is or is to be used— (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 40)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the data is not used for that purpose unless and until those grounds cease to be applicable to the data, whether by the rectification of the data or otherwise; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the data is erased;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where it is practicable in all the circumstances of the case to know that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: personal data disclosed on or after the appointed day to a third party is materially inaccurate having regard to the purpose (including any directly related purpose) for which the data is or is to be used by the third party; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that data was inaccurate at the time of such disclosure,

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is informed that the data is inaccurate; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: is provided with such particulars as will enable the third party to rectify the data having regard to that purpose. (Amended 18 of 2012 s. 40)
